articles.headline: Foreclose Deal Near, State Officials Say
articles.snippet: Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa, said several issues remain, including the question of who would be helped with the proceeds from any so-called global settlement with the banks.
articles.abstract: Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa, said several issues remain, including the question of who would be helped with the proceeds from any so-called global settlement with the banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A broad agreement could be struck within two months to overhaul how millions of foreclosures are handled by the nation’s biggest banks and to expand the use of home loan modifications, according to Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa.

articles.headline: Debit Card Fees Prompt a Push Near Deadline
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is scheduled to write rules for debit card fees in April, and lobbyists for merchants and the banking industry are determined to sway the outcome.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is scheduled to write rules for debit card fees in April, and lobbyists for merchants and the banking industry are determined to sway the outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It seemed a good idea last year, when the financial crisis had turned banks into Public Enemy No. 1 and lawmakers were looking for ways to reward consumers still bitter about billion-dollar bailouts and executive bonuses.

articles.headline: Exchanges Duel for Customers
articles.snippet: In a fight for listings, the Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange are stealing companies from one another as the number of companies listing on the two exchanges dwindles.
articles.abstract: In a fight for listings, the Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange are stealing companies from one another as the number of companies listing on the two exchanges dwindles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, when Continental and United Airlines were merging and deciding where to list the new company’s shares, the New York Stock Exchange offered to sponsor ceremonies for airline executives at the open and close of trading in Paris and New York. It also agreed to buy advertisements in the airline’s magazine to herald the listing.

articles.headline: Drawing U.S. Crowds With Anti-Islam Message
articles.snippet: Brigitte Gabriel, who is from Lebanon, is getting strong reactions for warning that America is under threat from radical Islam.
articles.abstract: Brigitte Gabriel, who is from Lebanon, is getting strong reactions for warning that America is under threat from radical Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH  Brigitte Gabriel bounced to the stage at a Tea Party convention last fall. She greeted the crowd with a loud Texas “Yee-HAW,” then launched into the same gripping personal story she has told in hundreds of churches, synagogues and conference rooms across the United States:

articles.headline: Discord Fills Washington on Possible Libya Intervention
articles.snippet: Nearly three weeks after Libya erupted in what may now turn into a protracted civil war, the politics of military intervention grow more complicated each day.
articles.abstract: Nearly three weeks after Libya erupted in what may now turn into a protracted civil war, the politics of military intervention grow more complicated each day.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Nearly three weeks after Libya erupted in what may now turn into a protracted civil war, the politics of military intervention to speed the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi grow more complicated by the day  for both the White House and Republicans.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Mog, the Digital Music Service, Takes Aim at the TV and the Car
articles.snippet: Mog, a streaming music service, will be incorporated into Internet-ready TVs and other devices made by LG, Samsung and Vizio, as well as in BMW’s Mini car line.
articles.abstract: Mog, a streaming music service, will be incorporated into Internet-ready TVs and other devices made by LG, Samsung and Vizio, as well as in BMW’s Mini car line.
articles.lead_paragraph: The next frontier for digital music is not a tablet or a smartphone, but two items that have been part of everyday life for decades: the car and the television set.

articles.headline: Libyan War Traps Poor Immigrants at Tripoli’s Edge
articles.snippet: Migrant workers, many of them illegal immigrants from Ghana and Nigeria, live amid piles of garbage and face persecution from all sides of the Libyan conflict in a makeshift camp near Tripoli’s airport.
articles.abstract: Migrant workers, many of them illegal immigrants from Ghana and Nigeria, live amid piles of garbage and face persecution from all sides of the Libyan conflict in a makeshift camp near Tripoli’s airport.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — As wealthier nations send boats and planes to rescue their citizens from the violence in Libya, a new refugee crisis is taking shape on the outskirts of Tripoli, where thousands of migrant workers from sub-Saharan Africa have been trapped with scant food and water, no international aid and little hope of escape.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Scott Sayare

articles.headline: Taking a Risk for Rare Earths
articles.snippet: If it can prove that rare earth metals can be processed safely, Malaysia thinks it can reap rewards by breaking China’s market dominance.
articles.abstract: If it can prove that rare earth metals can be processed safely, Malaysia thinks it can reap rewards by breaking China’s market dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUANTAN, Malaysia  A colossal construction project here could help determine whether the world can break China’s chokehold on the strategic metals crucial to products as diverse as Apple’s iPhone, Toyota’s Prius and Boeing’s smart bombs.
